long_desc.thetext:
The following test fails in the latest I build with the following trace:
C:\Users\HUDSONBUILD\AppData\Local\Temp\comptest\run.1351741384979\regression\bin: does not exist
java.io.FileNotFoundException: C:\Users\HUDSONBUILD\AppData\Local\Temp\comptest\run.1351741384979\regression\bin: does not exist at com.sun.tools.javac.file.JavacFileManager.getOutputDirectory(JavacFileManager.java:840) at com.sun.tools.javac.file.JavacFileManager.setLocation(JavacFileManager.java:820) at org.eclipse.jdt.compiler.tool.tests.CompilerInvocationTests.test004_no_dash_d_option(CompilerInvocationTests.java:391) at org.eclipse.jdt.core.tests.util.CompilerTestSetup.run(CompilerTestSetup.java:55) at org.eclipse.test.EclipseTestRunner.run(EclipseTestRunner.java:650) at org.eclipse.test.EclipseTestRunner.run(EclipseTestRunner.java:305) at org.eclipse.test.CoreTestApplication.runTests(CoreTestApplication.java:36) at org.eclipse.test.CoreTestApplication.run(CoreTestApplication.java:32) at org.eclipse.equinox.internal.app.EclipseAppContainer.callMethodWithException(EclipseAppContainer.java:587) at org.eclipse.equinox.internal.app.EclipseAppHandle.run(EclipseAppHandle.java:198) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.internal.adaptor.EclipseAppLauncher.runApplication(EclipseAppLauncher.java:110) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.internal.adaptor.EclipseAppLauncher.start(EclipseAppLauncher.java:79) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.run(EclipseStarter.java:353) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.run(EclipseStarter.java:180) at org.eclipse.equinox.launcher.Main.invokeFramework(Main.java:629) at org.eclipse.equinox.launcher.Main.basicRun(Main.java:584) at org.eclipse.equinox.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:1438) at org.eclipse.equinox.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:1414) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:34)
*** Bug 405691 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

This occurred again in build N20130414-2000. Nothing seems to have changed in the test or the code being tested. This build is using the same JVM as the previous builds, which had so problem. Will have to wait and see if it occurs again.
No progress on this yet. Not going to happen in M7
Have had several builds without this failure. Haven't progressed on identifying the failure's cause. Moving out of 4.3.
Failed again: http://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/downloads/drops4/I20130804-2300/testresults/html/org.eclipse.jdt.compiler.tool.tests_win32.win32.x86_7.0.html

(In reply to comment #5) > Failed again: > http://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/downloads/drops4/I20130804-2300/ > testresults/html/org.eclipse.jdt.compiler.tool.tests_win32.win32.x86_7.0.html
The failure is artificially reproduced by following the steps listed below:
1. In Until static constructor block, make the following modification File dateDir = new File(dir, "run."+"hello"/*System.currentTimeMillis()*/); so as to create a clash.
2a. Run CompilerInvocationTests.java in debug mode 2b. Break at CompilerInvocationTests.java: test004_no_dash_d_option : javacStandardJavaFileManager.setLocation
3a. Run BatchCompilerTests.java in debug mode 3b. Pickup a relevant test, I used test028. Break in that if you want to reconfirm the clash (which is not really necessary. Allow the test to complete including the tearDown() to make sure that the dir gets cleaned.
4. Resume the test004_no_dash_d_option(). A FileNotFound Exception will be triggered.
Here the assumption is that these two might be running in parallel. Even if this is the case, the chances of OUTPUT_DIR being identical are also quite less. And in addition, the issue recurring in the same test, test004_no_dash_d_option(), is also lessening the possibility of the above scenario of race condition being the actual culprit for the failure.
Opinions welcome here before going ahead with any proposals..

(In reply to comment #6)
> 1. In Until static constructor block, make the following modification File ^^^^ In eclipse/jdt/core/tests/util/Util.java..

(In reply to comment #6) > (In reply to comment #5) > > Failed again: > > http://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/downloads/drops4/I20130804-2300/ > > testresults/html/org.eclipse.jdt.compiler.tool.tests_win32.win32.x86_7.0.html > > > The failure is artificially reproduced by following the steps listed below:
I am not sure if the tests are run parallel. It's possible that the previous test can have an impact if it's trying to remove the output location. From the test results page, it would be CompilerToolTests. But I don't see any suspect looking at the tests in CompilerToolTests, though.

(In reply to comment #8) > (In reply to comment #6) > > (In reply to comment #5) > > > Failed again: > > > http://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/downloads/drops4/I20130804-2300/ > > > testresults/html/org.eclipse.jdt.compiler.tool.tests_win32.win32.x86_7.0.html > > > > > > The failure is artificially reproduced by following the steps listed below: > > I am not sure if the tests are run parallel. It's possible that the previous > test can have an impact if it's trying to remove the output location. From > the test results page, it would be CompilerToolTests. But I don't see any > suspect looking at the tests in CompilerToolTests, though.
The tests might run in parallel depending on your setup, e.g. if you use ActiveTestSuite or ParallelComputer.
It looks like this test class assumes that the tests are running in a specific order which is not guaranteed when using JRE 7 or newer.

One thing to note is that the resolution of the samples you get from System.currentTimeMillis() can be significantly less than what the 1ms precision would optimally allow. On my machine, sampling a 10000ms interval in a busy-loop gives 640 distinct values, utilizing only 6,4% of the available values.
One second of sampled values looks like this: 6 22 37 53 68 84 100 115 131 147 162 178 193 209 225 240 256 272 287 303 318 334 350 365 381 397 412 428 443 459 475 490 506 522 537 553 568 584 600 615 631 647 662 678 693 709 725 740 756 772 787 803 818 834 850 865 881 897 912 928 943 959 975 990

(In reply to comment #10) > One thing to note is that the resolution of the samples you get from > System.currentTimeMillis() can be significantly less than what the 1ms > precision would optimally allow. On my machine, sampling a 10000ms interval > in a busy-loop gives 640 distinct values, utilizing only 6,4% of the > available values. > > One second of sampled values looks like this: 6 22 37 53 68 84 100 115 131 > 147 162 178 193 209 225 240 256 272 287 303 318 334 350 365 381 397 412 428 > 443 459 475 490 506 522 537 553 568 584 600 615 631 647 662 678 693 709 725 > 740 756 772 787 803 818 834 850 865 881 897 912 928 943 959 975 990
Are you sure you commented on the right bug?

That was just a side note about the code snippet "new File(dir, "run."+"hello"/*System.currentTimeMillis()*/); " from comment 6 and the likelihood of collisions when such code is executed concurrently. And it was a neat test to try out :)
Again failed at http://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/downloads/drops4/M20130821-0800/testResults.php Will implement a solution for the "cause" identified in comment 6

(In reply to comment #9)
> The tests might run in parallel depending on your setup, e.g. if you use > ActiveTestSuite or ParallelComputer. > > It looks like this test class assumes that the tests are running in a > specific order which is not guaranteed when using JRE 7 or newer.
Given the above info, the more probable case is that of surrounding tests (test003_dash_d_option in particular) interfering with the output directory which could explain the repeated case of test004_dash_d_option failure.
Planning to add the thread id by default to the OUTPUT_DIR and clean only that dir.

(In reply to comment #14) > (In reply to comment #9) > > > The tests might run in parallel depending on your setup, e.g. if you use > > ActiveTestSuite or ParallelComputer. > > > > It looks like this test class assumes that the tests are running in a > > specific order which is not guaranteed when using JRE 7 or newer. > > Given the above info, the more probable case is that of surrounding tests > (test003_dash_d_option in particular) interfering with the output directory > which could explain the repeated case of test004_dash_d_option failure. > > Planning to add the thread id by default to the OUTPUT_DIR and clean only > that dir.
May I also suggest to add the tests explicitly to the suite so that the order of the tests is same as the test method declarations? Refer to ClasspathTests as an example.

(In reply to comment #15) > (In reply to comment #14) > > (In reply to comment #9) > > > > > The tests might run in parallel depending on your setup, e.g. if you use > > > ActiveTestSuite or ParallelComputer. > > > > > > It looks like this test class assumes that the tests are running in a > > > specific order which is not guaranteed when using JRE 7 or newer. > > > > Given the above info, the more probable case is that of surrounding tests > > (test003_dash_d_option in particular) interfering with the output directory > > which could explain the repeated case of test004_dash_d_option failure. > > > > Planning to add the thread id by default to the OUTPUT_DIR and clean only > > that dir. > > May I also suggest to add the tests explicitly to the suite so that the > order of the tests is same as the test method declarations? Refer to > ClasspathTests as an example.
You might want to use org.eclipse.test.OrderedTestSuite.

(In reply to comment #16) > You might want to use org.eclipse.test.OrderedTestSuite.
It's in the 'org.eclipse.test.performance' project ('eclipse.platform.releng' repo).

Created attachment 234730 Proposed Patch
- thread name based ouput directory - ordered test runs using the OrderedTestSuite. - This patch addresses the master branch (Will upload the beta java8 version once this version gets committed).

(In reply to comment #18) > Created attachment 234730 [details] > Proposed Patch
Couple of questions/comments:
1. BatchCompilerTest#getOutputDirectory is redundant. Just omitting it will be enough.
2. Implementation of EMPTY_STRING_MATCHER.#match(String, BatchCompilerTest) looks suspicious. Why don't we just call single parameter version like in other places? We don't want this to bite us later.
Finally, this includes tons of changes, albeit most of them just refactoring changes. And all of these are test only changes.
Even though I am fine with this fix or Luna, do we really want to push this for 4.3.1? We may not achieve much, I guess. Given how sporadically this failure occurs, we can't be sure if the fix was really addressed, at least during the last few days of 4.3.1 cycle.
Dani, do you still want this for 4.3.1?

(In reply to comment #19) > (In reply to comment #18) > > Created attachment 234730 [details] [diff] > > Proposed Patch > > Couple of questions/comments: > > 1. BatchCompilerTest#getOutputDirectory is redundant. Just omitting it will > be enough. > > 2. Implementation of EMPTY_STRING_MATCHER.#match(String, BatchCompilerTest) > looks suspicious. Why don't we just call single parameter version like in > other places? We don't want this to bite us later. > > Finally, this includes tons of changes, albeit most of them just refactoring > changes. And all of these are test only changes. > > Even though I am fine with this fix or Luna, do we really want to push this > for 4.3.1? We may not achieve much, I guess. Given how sporadically this > failure occurs, we can't be sure if the fix was really addressed, at least > during the last few days of 4.3.1 cycle. > > Dani, do you still want this for 4.3.1?
To me this looks like trial and error. You should first confirm that the order is causing the problem. This can be done by using the order which caused one of the failures. If it is really the order, then the fix should be easy and also applicable to 4.3.1.

Created attachment 234737 Proposed Patch
>If it is really the order, then the fix should be easy and also applicable to 4.3.1. Dani: Right. Order causes the issue to surface - the issue being the parent directory not created - solved by simply replacing mkdir() by mkdirs() which creates the non-existing parent directories as well. [I am obsoleting the "thread-safe" patch for now by this simple patch - maybe we can take up the implementation of thread-safe test cases as another activity later"

(In reply to comment #21) > Created attachment 234737 [details] > Proposed Patch
Looks good. So, we don't need the tests to be ordered, do we?

(In reply to comment #22) > (In reply to comment #21) > > Created attachment 234737 [details] > > Proposed Patch > > Looks good. So, we don't need the tests to be ordered, do we?
Right. Committed to master via http://git.eclipse.org/c/jdt/eclipse.jdt.core.git/commit/?id=dcc90ac4a7bfde7969fd3cd0f96c9b0fd4416eec

(In reply to comment #23) > Right. Committed to master via > http://git.eclipse.org/c/jdt/eclipse.jdt.core.git/commit/ > ?id=dcc90ac4a7bfde7969fd3cd0f96c9b0fd4416eec
Right, so this didn't create any problems in latest N build. After seeing the results of today's I build, we can cherry-pick this for R4_3_maintenance for tomorrow's M build.

The I build went alright too.
Dani, can we push this in for 4.3.1 already?

(In reply to comment #25) > The I build went alright too. > > Dani, can we push this in for 4.3.1 already?
Yes.

(In reply to comment #26) > (In reply to comment #25) > > The I build went alright too. > > > > Dani, can we push this in for 4.3.1 already? > > Yes.
Master Commit via: http://git.eclipse.org/c/jdt/eclipse.jdt.core.git/commit/?id=dcc90ac4a7bfde7969fd3cd0f96c9b0fd4416eec
4.3 Maintenance commit via: http://git.eclipse.org/c/jdt/eclipse.jdt.core.git/commit/?id=8d2474b2919a8343f623c218645a6257cbdc5012
Verified for 4.3.1 that there were no failures with build M20130828-0800. Previous builds off master went well too.
